title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Hello all,
Received this one and it would not boot past the apple logo. Well, it seemed like it would loose power or reset just a second after the apple showed up. So, with no physical damage on the motherboard, i took a stab at the bios. Pulled it off and stuck another on. It ended up booting up, so I copied the original bios to another and stuck it on there.

Boots up fine ever time, but - now it believes there is a magsafe always connecetd
- with magsafe conneced
- without magsafe connected
- with dcin board unplugged from the board

Addapter_Sense always has 3.4v on it when the battery is connected.

I have preformed a SMC reset, PRAM reset, and replaced U7000 with no change.

Would the SMC be the next step?

Thanks all and have a great day!

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: That means ACOK is being held high by something. Check if that really is the case and check J6100 for corrosion.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Ahhh, that makes more sense... So, Ill check that out tomorrow when I get into the shop. J6100 looked good from what I remember. I didn't see any sorts of liquid damage and I did go over the board 3 times or so, because I was at a loss. Jtag or similar looking connectors are normally ones i investigate first.

So, if not J6100. I should check out
R5187
Replace U7100
U7001
and if i get that far and still no luck it would be the SMC?

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
So, seems I have a 20ohm short between ppbus_g3h and acok. That was with R5187 removed. I replaced U7001 and its still there.
Causes could be could be
U7100 or the SMC at this point, Correct? As they both have a path to g3h. Most likely though, it would be U7100?

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Update. I have now removed U7100, U7001 and R5187 and the 20ohm short is still there.
Before I pull the SMC i want to see if you have any ideas. Also, yes, J6100 has no corrosion. ACOK is being held high.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: A pull up to PPBUS would cause 12V on ACOK...weird. As the SMC has no connection to PPBUS I suspect the short will be inside the board. But SMC is the last component so pull it.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: well, i sure messed that one up. I guess before my coffee. I said ppbus_g3H but i meant PP3v42_g3h. I have a 20ohm short between pp3v42_g3h and SMC_BC_ACOK. Still pull the smc?

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Well yeah that could very well be the SMC then. There is nothing else left on this line.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
SMC swapped out and now the ACOK is working fine. How odd.

Another random thing, The system reports that its SN is Not Available. What is that related to? It is running High Sierra

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Was U6100 messed with? Read the dump, upload it, give serial if you want it fixed.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
I did replace u6100 - but I copied the old one to the new one. I'll upload it tomorrow - or I guess I could stick the original one back on?
Now my question would be, why did my copy and verify not go how it was supposed to?

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Thanks Duke!
So, i wrote this bios, installed it and am getting a problem detecting the ssd (blinking folder icon)

I just installed the original bios chip with its programming (the dump i sent) and it boots up fine.

Can a bad bios value cause no ssd recognition? (i did not try a bootable disk to see if under disk manager it was recognized)

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Probably APFS problem only with 10.12/13. My BIOS is not APFS updated yet. Reinstall 10.13 over the existing install and it will update the EFI. Or if you don't want to take any risks install 10.11 on another SSD and then update that to 10.13. The old SSD should then work again.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Would installing to an external USB ssd work for this?

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Dunno if it will run the EFI update from USB.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: I just I could make a time machine backup - they need their data data on this one, and it's already made me nervous a few times. Then try the reinstall

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: That would work too of course. As long as you start out with 10.11 and update to the latest it will work. Maybe you can do it directly if you boot it from the internet recovery, never tried that.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: You can also force flash the EFI update. That way you save a lot of time with installations, updates and backups

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: There is no separate EFI updates for APFS support unless you have spent the time digging them out of a 10.12/13 installation package. Please link me to the update if you have it.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
I spent the time already. Here are 10.13.5 EFI payloads. I am also using these for cleaning ME etc.

Just put them on a USB installer and run from Terminal:

bless -mount / -firmware "/EFIPayloads/" --recovery -verbose
shutdown -r now

[URL="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1GBFxzeiy_Dw5R4GhreUGyjFBQkkabFER/view?usp=sharing"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1GBF...ew?usp=sharing[/URL]

Do you also want the SMC Payloads and JSONs ??

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message: Thanks for that! Saves some times installing 10.13 after board swaps and BIOS fixes.

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Your welcome. Saves a lot of time in the long run :-)

Especially in cases like this particular one that only need APFS support activated.

I know Duke (and several others in here) knows what to do. But to other people that want to play around with these files - be aware! Use the correct file for the specific machine or else you're going to waste the time which was meant to be saved :-)

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected

title: 820-3476 - Always thinks magsafe adapter is connected
message:
Yeah I've been doing forced-updates for years (you may have even been the one that showed me how several years back on AR forums!), but didn't have files for the 2015+ models, so only for <2014. This will help with the newer stuff, too, and also really aid in cleaning some of those pesky ME regions. Starting in 2015, they seem to be much more finicky, and even good files from one board sometimes don't work on another (I mean, no chime, nothing). Helps to have the actual file and then force-update like this; so thank you again! This is also key to fixing a lot of the iSight issues on 3435/3437 boards that get killed from cleaning ME, etc.

This reminds me of a question, actually, and you might be able to help! On boards that have a new (newest?) version of EFI update, you get an error when trying to force-update just to clean ME region, which I imagine is because you can't force an update if it detects the newest version (or same version as the one you're trying to force). You also can't force-update to an older version; usually I have to pull the chip, manually write an older version, then force update to current version again. My question is: Is there a way around this? Is there any way to force it to update regardless if the present EFI version is current? In the event of a suspected damaged ME region, etc. Would sure save time in those cases.

So for this situation, for example: 2015 A1502 with confirmed damaged ME, but also most-current firmware version; either clean ME or load from another board to allow boot, but might cause ME-related issues as expected sometimes, so need to update to "fix", just in case; load up USB with scap folder, force-update via terminal, but get error because the current version matches the one you're attempting to force-update to board. Now what? Take hours trying to find an older version that will actually work, then proceed to update (current procedure), or some terminal command that will force the update regardless of the version present? Does this make sense?
